per_query.query_text: Section 87103(a) disqualification business entity investment financial interest
Does a planning commissioner need to recuse if they provide consulting services to a business that operates at the airport the commission oversees?

A city council member owns a home within a landscaping and lighting assessment district. The council must vote on the annual levy for the district, which funds maintenance of streetlights, medians, and parks in the area. The assessment would apply to all properties in the district, including the council member's home.
real property 500 feet proximity recusal Regulation 18702.2 zoning decision
Can a city council member vote on a street widening project if their residence is 370 feet from the project boundary?

A planning commissioner owns a rental property approximately 450 feet from a proposed mixed-use development site. The planning commission must approve the project's environmental impact report. The development would add 200 residential units and ground-floor retail. The commissioner's rental property is currently valued at $650,000 and generates $2,800 per month in rent.
Section 87103(c) source of income disqualification employer $500 threshold
Is a school board member disqualified from voting on a contract with a nonprofit organization that employs her?

A planning commissioner has a contract with a major technology company to write a book about urban design. The technology company has submitted an application to the planning commission for a campus expansion. The commissioner's book contract provides $75,000 in royalties over two years. The company became a source of income when the contract was signed six months ago.
Section 87103(d) gift disqualification $250 threshold reportable gift donor
Must a council member recuse from a redevelopment decision if the applicant gave the council member a gift exceeding $250 in the past year?
Section 87103(e) personal financial effect official expenses income assets
Does a council member have a conflict of interest when voting on development permits if the member's adult child works for a company that supplies materials to the developer?

A Fort Bragg city council member owns a small retail business located 800 feet from a 420-acre former mill site that is the subject of a major redevelopment plan. Over half of the businesses in the city are located within 1,000 feet of the mill site. The council must approve a specific plan for the redevelopment, which would include new commercial zoning and infrastructure improvements.
Government Code 1090 self-dealing financial interest contract void ab initio
Can a county board member who serves as an unpaid trustee of a nonprofit hospital vote on the county's Medi-Cal managed care contract with that hospital?

A water district board member is also a partner in an engineering firm. The water district is considering awarding a $2 million contract for pipeline design services. The engineering firm has not submitted a bid, but a subcontractor relationship with the winning bidder is likely. Section 1090 prohibits the entire board from entering the contract if any member has a financial interest.
post-employment revolving door one-year ban permanent ban Section 87400 former official
Can a retired state agency deputy director work as a consultant on a lawsuit involving a project she supervised while in government, if she would be assisting the state rather than opposing it?
public generally exception Regulation 18703 significant segment financial effect indistinguishable

A Half Moon Bay city council member owns a historic home located within a proposed redevelopment area. The council must vote on adopting the redevelopment plan. The member argues that many other property owners in the area would also be affected and that the financial impact on her property is no different from the impact on the public generally.
legally required participation rule of necessity Regulation 18707 quorum conflict
Can a conflicted board member participate in a decision if their recusal would prevent the board from having a quorum to act?
Section 1091 1091.5 remote interest noninterest exception contract abstain

Does a city council member's ownership of less than 3% of a corporation's shares qualify as a remote interest exception under Section 1091, allowing the council to approve a contract with that corporation?
spouse community property income disqualification conflict of interest 87103
Is a school board member required to report and potentially disqualify based on her husband's salary from a private company when they hold their assets as community property?
common law conflict of interest incompatible offices fiduciary duty People v. Darby

A city council member is also a licensed stockbroker. One of his brokerage clients is an engineer who does development work in the city. The council member may not have a financial interest that triggers the Political Reform Act, but there may be common law conflict of interest concerns arising from the personal business relationship with a party who regularly appears before the council.
82015 contribution definition payment political purpose behest candidate

A senior community offers a city council member space on its electronic reader board to display the council member's name, photo, and contact information alongside informational content about upcoming public meetings. The council member supplies the content herself and no city staff time is used. Does accepting this communication constitute a contribution to the council member under Section 82015?
85800 85801 campaign fund expenditure personal use governmental purpose
Can a state senator use campaign funds to pay for a conference on the lobbying process for local public officials in his district, including meals, hotel rooms, and transportation for panelists?

Does a city's practice of tagging council members on its official Facebook page constitute a prohibited mass mailing under Section 89001, given that Facebook posts are electronic rather than tangible items?
84308 subcontractor contribution appointive board disqualification entitlement for use

An engineering firm is named as a subcontractor in a contract proposal before a county transportation commission. The firm's principal made a $500 contribution to a commission member at the direction of the prime contractor. Must the commission member disqualify herself from voting on the contract under Section 84308?
Can a county establish a single central filing agency for campaign statements covering both city and county jurisdictions under the Political Reform Act?
85304 transfer ban candidate controlled committee slate mailer contribution limits
May a candidate-controlled committee make independent expenditures to support other candidates after the court in Reed v. FPPC struck down Section 85501?

A political party's county central committee has already contributed the maximum allowed to a supervisor candidate under the county's local contribution limits. The party now wants to pay for phone banking and text messaging to its registered voters in the supervisor's district urging them to support the candidate. Are these payments exempt from contribution limits as member communications under Section 85312?
84224 behested payment elected officer fundraising governmental purpose reporting $5000 threshold

The State Treasurer chairs a government board that is statutorily directed to raise private funds for a children's savings program. Must the Treasurer report these solicited donations as behested payments under Section 84224, and does the charitable organization safe harbor in Regulation 18215.3(b) apply if the Treasurer is not featured in the solicitation?
What are the requirements for a political committee to qualify as a broad based political committee under Section 85102(d), and how do the contribution limits differ?
89501 89502 honorarium ban designated employee op-ed articles
Can an elected city council member who runs a speaking and writing business continue to accept fees for paid speeches after taking office under the bona fide business exception to the honorarium ban?
Section 89503 gift limit exemption part-time governing board higher education reporting Form 700

A state agency is sponsoring a charity golf tournament open to employees, vendors, and the general public. A designated employee in the agency's project management office is collecting donated items from vendors valued under $200 each to use as raffle prizes. Are the items she collects considered reportable gifts to her, and are prizes won by designated employees at the raffle considered gifts or income?
Does Section 89506(a)(2) exempt travel payments from the gift limit when a foreign government pays for a local elected official's international trip to promote trade and economic development?
89518 campaign funds candidate self-compensation consulting services vendor

A county supervisor who is also a licensed general contractor wants to use campaign funds from his officeholder account to pay a $500 speaker's fee to attend and present at a local economic outlook seminar. The fee includes a display booth and a table for eight at the luncheon. He plans to invite other county officials as his guests and will speak on county demographics, land use policies, and economic development priorities. Is this a permissible expenditure of campaign funds under the personal use restrictions?
lobbyist registration renewal vs new registration 86103 ethics course conditional certification

A nonprofit consumer advocacy organization participates in Public Utilities Commission ratemaking proceedings by submitting oral and written testimony at public hearings. The organization also employs a contract lobbyist to represent a related entity before the Legislature. Must the organization report on Form 635 the compensation it pays to attorneys and expert witnesses for PUC proceedings, and can it exclude payments for preparing written testimony?

Can a registered lobbying firm host a $2,500 congratulatory reception for newly elected legislators if the pro rata cost per attendee exceeds $10, or must a third party such as a client city independently pay for the event?
placement agent contingency fee 86205(f) percentage of assets under management public retirement system

Our lobbying firm assists school districts in applying for state School Facility Program grants. We compile application materials, meet with state agency staff to answer questions, and explain how projects meet funding criteria. May we charge a fee calculated as a percentage of the grant funds ultimately awarded to our client, or does Section 86205 prohibit this as a contingency fee?
section 89001 government newsletter mass mailing public expense elected officer photograph regulation 18901

A county water district wants to mail an informational flyer about upcoming rate increases to all 15,000 ratepayers. The flyer includes a QR code linking to a promotional video featuring the district's elected board members discussing infrastructure improvements. The district's communications director asks whether the flyer or the linked video triggers the mass mailing prohibition under the Political Reform Act.
85801 85802 campaign funds personal use substantial personal benefit governmental purpose
Can a school board member use campaign funds to pay for travel and conference registration fees for an education conference related to her official duties?
Which entity is the code reviewing body for a joint powers authority's conflict of interest code when the JPA operates across multiple counties?
section 82041 definition local government agency Siegel four-factor test nonprofit public entity political reform act

Is a nonprofit trade association formed by California hospital districts considered a 'local government agency' under the Political Reform Act for purposes of the prohibition on using public moneys for political contributions?
84615 electronic filing campaign statements signature verification 81004 treasurer

Our organization employs registered lobbyists who are also attorneys. Must we count time they spend representing us as intervenors in insurance ratemaking hearings before the Insurance Commissioner as reportable lobbying activity under the Act?

A 501(c)(3) nonprofit dedicated to preserving the history of women in the California legislature is being formed. Several former state legislators who are now registered lobbyists have been invited to serve on its board of directors. The founder wants to know whether the Political Reform Act restricts lobbyists from serving in this capacity and what reporting obligations might arise if sitting legislators encourage donations to the organization.
